examples.title: BHK Interpretation
examples.statement: Explain the Brouwer-Heyting-Kolmogorov (BHK) interpretation of intuitionistic logic.

steps.title: Interpretation of connectives
steps.content:
A proof of $A \land B$ is a pair: (proof of $A$, proof of $B$)
A proof of $A \lor B$ is either (0, proof of $A$) or (1, proof of $B$)
A proof of $A \to B$ is a function that transforms any proof of $A$ into a proof of $B$

steps.title: Negation
steps.content:
$\lnot A$ means $A \to \bot$ (false).
A proof of $\lnot A$ is a function that transforms any proof of $A$ into a proof of a contradiction.

steps.title: Why excluded middle fails
steps.content:
To prove $A \lor \lnot A$, we need either a proof of $A$ or a proof of $\lnot A$.
For undecided propositions, we have neither.

solution.conclusion: Intuitionistic proofs are constructive: they provide witnesses or algorithms.

exercises.statement: Show that $\lnot\lnot A \to A$ is not provable in intuitionistic logic, but $A \to \lnot\lnot A$ is.

steps.title: Prove A → ¬¬A
steps.content:
Assume we have a proof $p$ of $A$.
We need a proof of $\lnot\lnot A$, i.e., $(\lnot A) \to \bot$.
Given any proof $q$ of $\lnot A$ (i.e., $A \to \bot$), apply $q$ to $p$ to get a proof of $\bot$.

steps.title: Why ¬¬A → A fails
steps.content:
A proof of $\lnot\lnot A$ tells us "there's no refutation of $A$".
But this doesn't construct an actual proof of $A$.

steps.title: Kripke countermodel
steps.content: In Kripke semantics, there are worlds where $\lnot\lnot A$ is true but $A$ is not yet known.

solution.conclusion: Double negation elimination requires the law of excluded middle.

examples.title: The Gödel Sentence
examples.statement: Explain how Gödel constructs a sentence that says "I am not provable."

steps.title: Gödel numbering
steps.content: Assign unique natural numbers to all symbols, formulas, and proofs.

steps.title: Provability predicate
steps.content:
Define $\text{Prov}(n)$ meaning "$n$ is the Gödel number of a provable formula."
This is expressible in arithmetic.

steps.title: Diagonal lemma
steps.content:
For any formula $\phi(x)$, there exists a sentence $G$ such that:
$G \leftrightarrow \phi(\ulcorner G \urcorner)$
where $\ulcorner G \urcorner$ is the Gödel number of $G$.

steps.title: Construct G
steps.content:
Apply diagonal lemma to $\lnot\text{Prov}(x)$:
$G \leftrightarrow \lnot\text{Prov}(\ulcorner G \urcorner)$

$G$ says "I am not provable."

solution.conclusion: If the system is consistent, $G$ is true but unprovable.

exercises.statement: Explain why adding the Gödel sentence $G$ as an axiom doesn't "fix" incompleteness.

steps.title: New system
steps.content: Let $T' = T + G$ be the system with $G$ added as axiom.

steps.title: Apply Gödel again
steps.content:
If $T'$ is consistent and sufficiently strong, Gödel's theorem applies to $T'$.
There exists $G'$ for $T'$ that is true but unprovable in $T'$.

steps.title: Iterate
steps.content: This process never terminates. Each consistent extension has its own Gödel sentence.

solution.conclusion: Incompleteness is intrinsic to sufficiently strong formal systems.

examples.title: The Second Incompleteness Theorem
examples.statement: State and explain Gödel's second incompleteness theorem.

steps.title: Statement
steps.content: If $T$ is a consistent, sufficiently strong formal system, then $T$ cannot prove its own consistency.

steps.title: Formalization of consistency
steps.content:
$\text{Con}(T)$ is the sentence $\lnot\text{Prov}(\ulcorner 0=1 \urcorner)$.
("$0=1$ is not provable")

steps.title: Key insight
steps.content:
Inside $T$, one can prove: $\text{Con}(T) \to G$.
("If I'm consistent, then $G$ is true.")

Since $G$ is unprovable in $T$, so is $\text{Con}(T)$.

solution.conclusion: No sufficiently strong consistent system can prove its own consistency.

exercises.statement: Why doesn't Gödel's second theorem apply to very weak systems like Presburger arithmetic?

steps.title: What Presburger arithmetic is
steps.content: Presburger arithmetic is the theory of $(\mathbb{N}, +)$ — natural numbers with addition only, no multiplication.

steps.title: Why Gödel doesn't apply
steps.content:
Gödel's theorems require coding of proofs as numbers, which needs multiplication.
Presburger arithmetic cannot express its own proof predicate.

steps.title: Presburger is decidable
steps.content:
In fact, Presburger arithmetic is complete and decidable!
There's an algorithm to decide any Presburger sentence.

solution.conclusion: The system must be "sufficiently strong" (able to do basic arithmetic) for Gödel's theorems.

examples.title: Categories and Functors
examples.statement: Define a category and give examples.

steps.title: Definition
steps.content:
A category $\mathcal{C}$ consists of:
- Objects: $\text{Ob}(\mathcal{C})$
- Morphisms: For each pair $(A, B)$, a set $\text{Hom}(A, B)$
- Composition: $\circ : \text{Hom}(B,C) \times \text{Hom}(A,B) \to \text{Hom}(A,C)$
- Identity: For each $A$, an $\text{id}_A \in \text{Hom}(A, A)$

steps.title: Axioms
steps.content:
Associativity: $(h \circ g) \circ f = h \circ (g \circ f)$
Identity: $\text{id}_B \circ f = f = f \circ \text{id}_A$

steps.title: Examples
steps.content:
**Set**: Objects are sets, morphisms are functions
**Grp**: Objects are groups, morphisms are homomorphisms
**Top**: Objects are topological spaces, morphisms are continuous maps

solution.conclusion: Categories abstract the notion of mathematical structure and structure-preserving maps.

exercises.statement: Show that any group $G$ can be viewed as a category with one object.

steps.title: Define the category
steps.content:
Objects: A single object $\star$
Morphisms: $\text{Hom}(\star, \star) = G$ (elements of the group)

steps.title: Define composition
steps.content: For $g, h \in G$: $h \circ g = hg$ (group multiplication)

steps.title: Verify axioms
steps.content:
Associativity: $(hg)f = h(gf)$ ✓ (group associativity)
Identity: $\text{id}_\star = e$ (group identity)
$e \cdot g = g = g \cdot e$ ✓

solution.conclusion: A group is a category with one object where every morphism is invertible.

sections.sectionTitle: A Natural Transformation between Vector Spaces

examples.title: The Double Dual
examples.statement: Show that there is a natural transformation from the identity functor to the double dual functor on finite-dimensional vector spaces.

steps.title: Define the map
steps.content:
For a vector space $V$, define $\eta_V : V \to V^{**}$ by:
$\eta_V(v)(f) = f(v)$ for $v \in V$, $f \in V^*$

steps.title: Check naturality
steps.content:
For a linear map $T: V \to W$, we need:
$T^{**} \circ \eta_V = \eta_W \circ T$

steps.title: Verify
steps.content:
$(T^{**}(\eta_V(v)))(g) = \eta_V(v)(T^*(g)) = T^*(g)(v) = g(T(v))$
$(\eta_W(T(v)))(g) = g(T(v))$

They agree!

solution.conclusion: $\eta$ is a natural transformation. For finite-dimensional spaces, it's a natural isomorphism.

exercises.statement: Why is the isomorphism $V \cong V^*$ for finite-dimensional $V$ not natural?

steps.title: The isomorphism requires a basis
steps.content:
Given a basis $\{e_1, \ldots, e_n\}$, we get dual basis $\{e_1^*, \ldots, e_n^*\}$.
Map: $e_i \mapsto e_i^*$

steps.title: Check naturality fails
steps.content:
For $T: V \to W$, naturality would require:
$T^* \circ \phi_W = \phi_V \circ T$
where $\phi$ is the isomorphism.

steps.title: Counterexample
steps.content:
Let $V = W = \mathbb{R}$, $T = 2 \cdot \text{id}$.
$T^*(f) = f \circ T = 2f$.

$\phi_V(1) = 1^*$ (the identity functional).
$T^*(\phi_W(1)) = 2 \cdot 1^* \neq \phi_V(2 \cdot 1) = \phi_V(2)$.

solution.conclusion: The isomorphism $V \cong V^*$ depends on the choice of basis and is not natural.
